message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Observer-Based Adaptive Fuzzy Tracking Control for Strict-Feedback Nonlinear Systems With Unknown Control Gain Functions
Paper Abstract: This article investigates the adaptive fuzzy output-feedback backstepping control design problem for uncertain strict-feedback nonlinear systems in the presence of unknown virtual and actual control gain functions and unmeasurable states. A fuzzy state observer is designed via fuzzy-logic systems, thus the unmeasurable states are estimated based on the designed fuzzy state observer. By constructing the logarithm Lyapunov functions and incorporating the property of the fuzzy basis functions and bounded control design technique into the adaptive backstepping recursive design, a novel observer-based adaptive fuzzy output-feedback control method is developed. The proposed fuzzy adaptive output-feedback backstepping control scheme can remove the restrictive assumptions in the previous literature that the virtual control gains and actual control gain functions must be constants. Furthermore, it can make the control system be semiglobally uniformly ultimately boundedness (SGUUB) and keep the observer and tracking errors to remain in a small neighborhood of the origin. The numerical simulation example is presented to validate the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme and theory.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Lyapunov function"

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov–Schmidt reduction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov%E2%80%93Schmidt_reduction"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Central limit theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem"},{"title":"Lyapunov vector - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_vector"},{"title":"Conley's fundamental theorem of dynamical systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conley's_fundamental_theorem_of_dynamical_systems"}]

## Lyapunov Function

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

### Definition and Characteristics

A Lyapunov function is a nonnegative scalar measure of a multi-dimensional state, and typically the function is defined to grow large when the system moves towards undesirable states.(no content)For certain classes of ODEs, the existence of Lyapunov functions is a necessary and sufficient condition for stability.

### Stability Conditions

If the equilibrium point is isolated, the Lyapunov-candidate-function is locally positive definite, and the time derivative of the Lyapunov-candidate-function is locally negative definite, then the equilibrium is proven to be locally asymptotically stable.

### Construction

While there is no general technique for constructing Lyapunov functions for ODEs, in many specific cases the construction of Lyapunov functions is known - for instance, quadratic functions suffice for systems with one state, and the solution of a particular linear matrix inequality provides Lyapunov functions for linear systems.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Tracking control"

Links: [{"title":"Control track - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_track"},{"title":"Mail Isolation Control and Tracking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mail_Isolation_Control_and_Tracking"},{"title":"Video tape tracking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_tape_tracking"},{"title":"Antenna tracking system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antenna_tracking_system"},{"title":"Satellite Control Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satellite_Control_Network"},{"title":"Fire-control radar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fire-control_radar"},{"title":"Time and attendance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_and_attendance"},{"title":"Fleet management software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fleet_management_software"},{"title":"Fixed assets management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fixed_assets_management"},{"title":"Traction control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traction_control_system"}]

I found several results for "tracking control." Here are the main definitions depending on the context:

## Video Tape Tracking

In a video tape recorder, tracking is a calibration adjustment which ensures that the spinning playback head is properly aligned with the helical scan signal written onto the tape.(no content)Most machines offer a manual or automatic tracking control to correct mismatches that occur due to manufacturing tolerances.

## Traction Control System

A traction control system (TCS) is typically a secondary function of the electronic stability control (ESC) on production motor vehicles, designed to prevent loss of traction (i.e., wheelspin) of the driven road wheels.

## Asset Tracking Control

Asset tracking software allows companies to track what assets it owns, where each is located, who has it, when it was checked out, when it is due for return, when it is scheduled for maintenance, and the cost and depreciation of each asset.

## Other Applications

An antenna tracking system tracks a primary antenna to follow a moving signal source, such as a communication satellite. Additionally, time and attendance systems are used to track and monitor when employees start and stop work and enable an employer to monitor their employees' working hours and late arrivals, early departures, time taken on breaks and absenteeism.

The term "tracking control" can refer to different systems depending on the context, but all involve monitoring and controlling the movement or alignment of something.

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Category:Nonlinear systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Nonlinear_systems"},{"title":"Nonlinear system identification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system_identification"},{"title":"Non-Linear Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-Linear_Systems"},{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Linear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_system"},{"title":"Linear stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_stability"},{"title":"Dynamical systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_systems_theory"},{"title":"Dynamical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_system"},{"title":"Limit cycle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limit_cycle"}]

## Search Results for "Nonlinear Systems"

Here's an overview of what the web search revealed about nonlinear systems:

### Definition
Nonlinear systems are systems whose behavior is not expressible as a linear function of its descriptors; that is, such systems are not linear. More formally, a nonlinear system is defined as any system that is not linear, that is any system that does not satisfy the superposition principle.

### Key Characteristics
Nonlinear systems do not follow the principle of superposition (linearity and homogeneity), may have multiple isolated equilibrium points, and may exhibit properties such as limit cycle, bifurcation, and chaos. Additionally, solutions of nonlinear systems may not exist for all times (finite escape time).

### Mathematical Challenges
One of the greatest difficulties of nonlinear problems is that it is not generally possible to combine known solutions into new solutions, whereas in linear problems, a family of linearly independent solutions can be used to construct general solutions through the superposition principle.

### Real-World Examples
Examples of nonlinear differential equations are the Navier–Stokes equations in fluid dynamics and the Lotka–Volterra equations in biology.(no content)Some aspects of the weather are seen to be chaotic, where simple changes in one part of the system produce complex effects throughout, and this nonlinearity is one of the reasons why accurate long-term forecasts are impossible with current technology.

### Applications
System identification applications include any system where the inputs and outputs can be measured, such as industrial processes, control systems, economic data, biology and the life sciences, medicine, and social systems.

## Search Results for "Nonlinear Systems"

Here's an overview of what the web search revealed about nonlinear systems:

### Definition
Nonlinear systems are systems whose behavior is not expressible as a linear function of its descriptors; that is, such systems are not linear. More formally, a nonlinear system is defined as any system that is not linear, that is any system that does not satisfy the superposition principle.

### Key Characteristics
Nonlinear systems do not follow the principle of superposition (linearity and homogeneity), may have multiple isolated equilibrium points, and may exhibit properties such as limit cycle, bifurcation, and chaos. Additionally, solutions of nonlinear systems may not exist for all times (finite escape time).

### Mathematical Challenges
One of the greatest difficulties of nonlinear problems is that it is not generally possible to combine known solutions into new solutions, whereas in linear problems, a family of linearly independent solutions can be used to construct general solutions through the superposition principle.

### Real-World Examples
Examples of nonlinear differential equations are the Navier–Stokes equations in fluid dynamics and the Lotka–Volterra equations in biology.(no content)Some aspects of the weather are seen to be chaotic, where simple changes in one part of the system produce complex effects throughout, and this nonlinearity is one of the reasons why accurate long-term forecasts are impossible with current technology.

### Applications
System identification applications include any system where the inputs and outputs can be measured, such as industrial processes, control systems, economic data, biology and the life sciences, medicine, and social systems.

Kokotovic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petar_V._Kokotovic"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Talk:Backstepping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Backstepping"},{"title":"Backpropagation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpropagation"},{"title":"Backstay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstay"},{"title":"Control reversal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_reversal"},{"title":"Take back control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Take_Back_Control"},{"title":"Exponential backoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_backoff"}]

## Results for "Backstepping Control"

Based on the search results, here's an overview of backstepping control:

### What is Backstepping?

Backstepping provides a recursive method for stabilizing the origin of a system in strict-feedback form.(no content)Backstepping is one of several nonlinear control techniques that normally take advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory.

### How It Works

The single-step procedure can be completed iteratively to stabilize an entire strict-feedback system. In each step, the smallest "unstabilized" single-step strict-feedback system is isolated, feedback is used to convert the system into a single-integrator system, and the resulting single-integrator system is stabilized.

### Key Concept

Backstepping is a method of taking a large and ugly nonlinear problem and stripping off all of the trivial layers so that you're left with a simpler system. Rather than having to design a controller for a 100th order system, you might use backstepping to show that all you really need to do is find a controller for a 2nd order system and then use backstepping to extend that controller to the 98th other orders.

### Historical Contribution

Petar V. Kokotovic has made contributions in nonlinear control, especially the backstepping stabilization method.

Web search results for query: "Adaptive control"

Links: [{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"},{"title":"Adaptive cruise control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_cruise_control"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Self-tuning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-tuning"},{"title":"Adaptive traffic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_traffic_control"},{"title":"Continuous monitoring and adaptive control (stormwater management) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_monitoring_and_adaptive_control_(stormwater_management)"},{"title":"Xbox Adaptive Controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_Adaptive_Controller#:~:text=The co-creator of the,much they could be ..."},{"title":"Real-time adaptive security - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_adaptive_security"},{"title":"File:Xbox Adaptive Controller V&A.JPG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Xbox_Adaptive_Controller_V&A.JPG"},{"title":"Adaptive autonomy","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_autonomy"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about adaptive control:

## Overview

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## How It Differs From Robust Control

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

## Foundations and Methods

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification.(no content)Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent. Both of these methods provide update laws that are used to modify estimates in real-time (i.e., as the system operates).

## Types and Categories

Adaptive control systems can be classified into several broad categories including model reference adaptive controllers (MRACs) and model identification adaptive controllers (MIACs), among others.

## Modern Applications

In recent times, adaptive control has been merged with intelligent techniques such as fuzzy and neural networks to bring forth new concepts such as fuzzy adaptive control.(no content)A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control. This body of work has focused on guaranteeing stability of a model reference adaptive control scheme using Lyapunov arguments.

Links: [{"title":"Proportional–integral–derivative controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proportional–integral–derivative_controller"},{"title":"Feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback"},{"title":"Closed-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed-loop_controller"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Feedback linearization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_linearization"},{"title":"Feed forward (control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feed_forward_(control)"},{"title":"Negative feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_feedback"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Linear–quadratic–Gaussian control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear–quadratic–Gaussian_control"},{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of output feedback control:

## Definition

Output feedback control, also known as closed-loop feedback control, is a control loop that incorporates feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

## How It Works

The information path in the system works as follows: process inputs (e.g., voltage applied to an electric motor) have an effect on the process outputs (e.g., speed or torque of the motor), which is measured with sensors and processed by the controller; the result (the control signal) is "fed back" as input to the process, closing the loop.(no content)The controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Practical Example

An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the driver has the ability to alter the desired set speed. The PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

## Advantages

Closed-loop controllers have advantages over open-loop controllers including disturbance rejection and guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties, when the model structure does not match perfectly the real process and the model parameters are not exact.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of output feedback control:

## Definition

Output feedback control, also known as closed-loop feedback control, is a control loop that incorporates feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

## How It Works

The information path in the system works as follows: process inputs (e.g., voltage applied to an electric motor) have an effect on the process outputs (e.g., speed or torque of the motor), which is measured with sensors and processed by the controller; the result (the control signal) is "fed back" as input to the process, closing the loop.(no content)The controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Practical Example

An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the driver has the ability to alter the desired set speed. The PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

## Advantages

Closed-loop controllers have advantages over open-loop controllers including disturbance rejection and guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties, when the model structure does not match perfectly the real process and the model parameters are not exact.

Links: [{"title":"Fuzzy logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_logic"},{"title":"Fuzzy control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_control_system"},{"title":"Fuzzy electronics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_electronics"},{"title":"Type-2 fuzzy sets and systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type-2_fuzzy_sets_and_systems"},{"title":"Fuzzy rule - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_rule"},{"title":"Fuzzy set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_set"},{"title":"Category:Fuzzy logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Fuzzy_logic"},{"title":"T-norm fuzzy logics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T-norm_fuzzy_logics"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"IEEE 1855 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_1855"}]

Here's an overview of fuzzy logic systems based on the search results:

## Definition and Fundamentals

Fuzzy logic is a mathematical system that analyzes analog input values in terms of logical variables that take on continuous values between 0 and 1, in contrast to classical or digital logic, which operates on discrete values of either 1 or 0.(no content)Fuzzy sets (also known as uncertain sets) are sets whose elements have degrees of membership and were introduced by Lotfi A. Zadeh in 1965 as an extension of the classical notion of set.

## Key Characteristics

In fuzzy logic applications, non-numeric values are often used to facilitate the expression of rules and facts, with linguistic variables such as age accepting values such as young and its antonym old.(no content)In a fuzzy rule, the premise and consequent can be true to a degree, instead of entirely true or entirely false.

## How Fuzzy Logic Systems Work

The most well-known system is the Mamdani rule-based one, which: fuzzifies all input values into fuzzy membership functions, executes all applicable rules in the rulebase to compute the fuzzy output functions, and de-fuzzifies the fuzzy output functions to get "crisp" output values.

## Applications

Fuzzy logic is used in control systems to allow experts to contribute vague rules such as "if you are close to the destination station and moving fast, increase the train's brake pressure"; these vague rules can then be numerically refined within the system.(no content)Fuzzy logic has been used for handwriting recognition in Sony pocket computers, helicopter flight aids, subway system controls, improving automobile fuel efficiency, single-button washing machine controls, automatic power controls in vacuum cleaners, and early recognition of earthquakes.

I've completed the web search for "Control theory tracking reference signal". Here are the key findings:

## Overview

The usual objective of control theory is to control a system, often called the plant, so its output follows a desired control signal, called the reference, which may be a fixed or changing value.

## Reference Signal and Tracking

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP).(no content)The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Improving Tracking Performance

Open-loop control is termed feedforward and serves to further improve reference tracking performance. Additionally, the primary objective of the tracking differentiator is to follow the transient profile of the reference signal, addressing the issue of sudden changes in the set point that occur in the conventional PID controller.

## How It Works in Closed-Loop Systems

A closed loop controller has a feedback loop which ensures the controller exerts a control action to give a process output the same as the "reference input" or "set point".(no content)One way to make the output of a system follow a desired reference signal is to compare the output of the plant to the desired output, and provide feedback to the plant to modify the output to bring it closer to the desired output.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence)

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis. Here's a summary of the work:

## Summary

I've analyzed the paper "Observer-Based Adaptive Fuzzy Tracking Control for Strict-Feedback Nonlinear Systems With Unknown Control Gain Functions" and extracted key technologies and methodologies.

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (proposes novel observer-based adaptive fuzzy control method)

**Identified Triples (7 total):**

1. **Fuzzy logic** (concept) - Uses: Foundation for designing the fuzzy state observer
2. **Backstepping** (method) - Uses: Core control design technique for strict-feedback systems
3. **Lyapunov function** (concept) - Uses: Proves stability of the closed-loop system
4. **Adaptive control** (method) - Uses: Handles unknown control gain functions
5. **Nonlinear system** (task) - Uses: Main problem domain for control design
6. **State observer** (method) - Proposes: Novel fuzzy observer for unmeasurable states
7. **Control theory** (concept) - Uses: Foundational principles for feedback and tracking

**Validation:** ✅ All checks passed successfully

The analysis satisfies the validation requirements:
- All 7 triples have at least 1 "uses" relation (papers always build on existing work)
- The contribution paper has at least 1 "proposes" (State observer)
- All Wikipedia URLs are valid and properly formatted

Sources:
- [Fuzzy logic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_logic)
- [Backstepping](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstepping)
- [Lyapunov function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function)
- [Adaptive control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control)
- [Nonlinear system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system)
- [State observer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer)
- [Control theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory)
